article.headline: LSU 58, Mississippi 53
article.story: OXFORD, Miss. (AP) -- LSU is still alive in the SEC West chase, thanks to some tough defense and clutch free throw shooting. Darrel Mitchell had 11 of his 16 points in the first half to lead the Tigers past Mississippi 58-53 on Wednesday night. LSU, picked in the preseason to finish third, remains tied with Alabama atop the division with one game remaining. "We've still got a chance to win it," LSU coach John Brady said. "If you had told me back in November that we would be in this position after the start we had, I would've had to question your thought process." Ole Miss closed to 49-48 with 4:29 remaining, but LSU held the Rebels to just two baskets the rest of the way and made 14 of 19 foul shots in the second half. "We've proven to ourselves that we can put ourselves in position to win these kind of games, but we just haven't finished," Ole Miss coach Rod Barnes said. The win kept the Tigers (18-8, 11-4) in the hunt for the division title and the No. 2 seed in next week's SEC tournament. LSU and No. 21 Alabama are tied for first place in the West heading into their weekend finales. Remarkably, LSU did it with their two top frontcourt threats -- Brandon Bass and Glen Davis -- held somewhat in check. Bass had nine of his 13 points from the free throw line -- he was just 2-of-12 from the field -- and added 10 rebounds, and Davis played through foul trouble and finished 1-of-6 with eight points. "If someone had told me that Brandon and Glen would have only three (combined) field goals and we would still win, I would've been surprised," Brady said. "We helped ourselves at the free throw line tonight and that made me feel better about it." LSU won for just the fourth time in 10 tries on the road this season. Marvin Moore had 15 points and Todd Abernethy finished with 12 for the Rebels. Tommie Eddie, Ole Miss' leading scorer, was held to six points -- nearly half his average. Ole Miss (13-15, 4-11) has lost nine games by 10 or fewer points this season. "I still wouldn't be surprised if we started winning games because we're that close," Barnes said. "We've just got to play like we have nothing to lose and lay it on the line." The Rebels are locked into fifth place in the division and after Sunday's regular-season finale at South Carolina, Ole Miss will play the opening game of the SEC tournament against the fourth-place team in the East. The loss makes the Rebels an even longer shot for an NIT berth; Ole Miss must beat the Gamecocks and win at least twice in the league tournament to gain eligibility. "We've got to find a way to get to the free throw line more and knock down more shots," Barnes said. "We haven't had those opportunities ... and that's got to turn around for us."

statistics.name: points
statistics.description: The number of points scored.

statistics.name: fieldGoals
statistics.description: Field Goal makes and attempts.

statistics.name: freeThrows
statistics.description: Free Throw makes and attempts.

statistics.name: assists
statistics.description: The number of times a player who passes the ball to a teammate in a way that leads to a score by field goal, meaning that he or she was "assisting" in the basket. There is some judgment involved in deciding whether a passer should be credited with an assist.

statistics.name: turnovers
statistics.description: The number of times a player loses possession to the other team.

statistics.name: minutes
statistics.description: The total number of minutes played.

statistics.name: assistTurnoverRatio
statistics.description: The average number of assists a player or team records per turnover

statistics.name: rebounds
statistics.description: The total number of rebounds (offensive and defensive).

statistics.name: defensiveRebounds
statistics.description: The number of times when the defense obtains the possession of the ball after a missed shot by the offense.
